2.80.text:
Tell me about your role as Chief Cashier
of The Bank of England. What does that

6.85.text: involve? It's pretty much everything there is to do with Bank of England

10.00.text: banknotes, so it's from design to distribution to destruction really

14.83.text:
making sure we've got enough bank notes
that are of good enough quality and also

18.88.text:
very difficult to counterfeit and those
are the two things that really led to our

22.93.text: decision to move to polymer. I've got a team of 240 staff, we're there to make sure that

27.64.text:
people can have all the notes they need
in their pockets when they need them.

31.09.text:
How did you get to be in this position
because you have worked at The Bank of

36.52.text:
Tell me about your progression to become
Chief Cashier. I've worked at the bank

40.60.text: since leaving university. I worked for an accountancy firm for about six months, but

44.71.text: then straight into The Bank of England where I've done a range of really

48.16.text: exciting and really varied jobs. I started looking at financing small

52.60.text:
businesses, I did some work supervising
wholesale market makers, I was a graduate

56.92.text:
recruitment manager for a while, which is a
fantastic chance to go out to promote

61.12.text:
the bank to people who thought well
that's gonna be quite stuffy

63.49.text: organisation you say no actually we're very normal, we're doing really

66.94.text: interesting policy work. I was then sponsored by the bank to do an MBA for

72.79.text:
a full year, which was again an amazing
opportunity great people to meet. Then

77.98.text:
I did quite of work looking at payment
and settlement systems, which some people

81.58.text:
call the 'plumbing' of the financial
system. I worked for the deputy governor as

85.87.text:
his private secretary - an incredible few
years, you really at the heart of the

89.77.text:
bank seeing everything that's going on,
how its governed, what the big policy

93.61.text:
decisions are and then I was involved in
the special resolution unit and

98.98.text:
Northern Rock and then I applied for a
job as Head of Notes Division - we have

102.97.text:
internal job advertising in the bank and I
was encouraged to apply and against the

108.25.text: whole load of competition I got that job. And then a couple of years ago I was asked

111.70.text:
by the government to become Chief
Cashier, which was just an amazing honour.

114.76.text: You describe part of your job as maintaining confidence in the currency.

119.59.text: What do you mean by that? So what we mean by maintaining confidence in the

123.04.text:
currency is really making sure we've got
the right number of banknotes in the right

127.27.text: place at the right time and that they're the notes people want. So one of the issues

132.16.text:
we get is what denominational mix do we
have. A while ago a lot of people were saying

136.28.text: there aren't enough fivers, so we had a sort of policy with the main ATM operators

142.64.text:
to get more fivers into ATMs. We've done
a lot of work looking at security of bank

147.32.text:
notes, to make them really difficult to
counterfeit so it's really making sure

150.98.text:
that people believe that there are
sufficient supply of Bank of England

154.28.text:
banknotes and that the notes they have
in their wallets are genuine and not

158.90.text:
counterfeit. I'm guessing it must be quite
hard to predict demand for notes at

162.44.text: times like Christmas and other times. Is that a bit of a challenge?

166.61.text:
Absolutely, that's one of the challenges
we're there to sort out. There are a number of

169.34.text:
sort of seasonal fluctuations and
Christmas, which you mentioned, is usually

172.91.text:
the busiest time of year for banknotes.
Also we'll see peaks around Easter and

178.13.text: bank holidays. When we were hosting the London Olympics 2012 we were

182.15.text:
forecasting demand for cash to make sure
we've got extra cash ready for that.

185.45.text: Sunny days like today, people are out buying ice cream and beer and you'll see

189.56.text: demand for cash there. So we need to make sure a. we've got enough notes printed, but

193.61.text:
b. the wholesale industry are there ready
to distribute them. Tell me about the

197.27.text:
new five pound note, sometimes called the
plastic fiver, because it's gonna have

200.33.text:
some extra security measures isn't it?
Yeah, so the new five pound note as you say

204.14.text:
it's on polymer which is type of plastic
and we had a sort of research and

207.50.text:
development project in the bank for a
number of years, really trying to think

210.98.text:
what is the best new note for The Bank
of England and for the public and we

216.41.text:
found that polymer notes they're made of
type of plastic and with the right

220.91.text:
security features on, are much more
difficult to counterfeit. They stay

224.21.text:
cleaner for longer, they're more durable and
if you put that together you've got sort

229.34.text:
of much more difficult to counterfeit
notes, better quality notes in your

232.97.text:
pockets, so sort of fewer tatty fivers. Also
because they're more durable they're

237.62.text:
ultimately better for the environment as we
don't need to replace so many, so a

241.85.text:
number of key drivers but really
importantly, although we as a central bank

245.75.text:
thought this makes sense, we know that
banknotes mean an awful lot to members of

249.56.text:
the public, so we had a public
consultation a number of roadshows -I was going all

253.40.text:
around the UK showing people the notes
back in 2013 before the final decision.

258.20.text:
And a real sense of excitement and
saying these notes are really cool,

263.15.text: some had used them in other countries, particular Australia, Canada, so we're introducing

268.07.text: them because we think that they're

269.66.text:
more secure, cleaner and stronger and the
public seem to really like the bright

275.24.text:
new designs. We're quite traditional
though when it comes to, I think, how we

279.17.text:
view money, so there hasn't been any
adverse reaction to the polymer plastic

283.49.text:
fiver? It was yeah it was really exciting
particularly for the team who spent a lot of time

287.75.text:
looking at this and I think we were finding
words like 'cool', which you don't

292.94.text:
necessarily hear associated with The
Bank of England and of the sort of

296.03.text: survey we did - so anyone who'd been to our stands at various shopping centers and

299.93.text: universities, also online we had some independent focus groups - 87%

303.98.text: of the public were in favour of moving to polymer. There have been a few stories

308.81.text:
saying well polymer notes will stick
together, which they don't - I mean if you

313.22.text: have a really large part of polymer notes you give them a quick flick and they'll be

316.55.text: alright. And some people thought plastic notes that's like a plastic

320.75.text:
credit card, can I fold it up in my wallet?
And actually polymer is very thin

325.22.text:
and flexible and definitely goes in
wallets. And I think a lot of people had used

328.85.text:
them overseas, so, no, really positive and
excited reaction. There was quite a campaign,

333.92.text:
wasn't there, a couple of years ago to make
sure that a woman was going to go on the

337.07.text:
reverse of the other bank note, so who
decides? How is that decision made?

343.10.text: Yeah you're absolutely right, so it's Churchill is coming out this autumn and then Jane

348.38.text:
Austen will appear on the ten pound note
in the summer 2017 and then Turner and yes

354.29.text:
when we announced that Churchill was
going to be on the note there was a

356.93.text: sort of slight concern that if he's going to be on the five pound note what

360.56.text:
about Elizabeth Fry, will be any women on
banknotes and we think it's really

365.63.text:
important that we use the banknotes to
celebrate people across the UK but also

370.58.text:
to look at sort of diversity and so
we've recently introduced a new process

374.99.text:
for deciding who's on the banknote and
last year the governor Mark Carney

379.10.text:
announced that we were having a public
nomination process to ask who people

384.05.text:
would like to feature on the new
20 pound note from the visual arts. We

387.65.text:
had a sort of phenomenal response rate -
about 30,000 people put forward names

392.33.text:
500, 590 different visual artists were
put forward and then we use an expert

398.27.text: committee with people with backgrounds in the arts so we had Baroness

402.17.text: Lola Young, Alice Rawsthorn - so great insights there - Andrew Graham-Dixon

406.58.text:
and a number of other people on the
committee whittled it down to five and then the

409.94.text:
governor made the final decision, but
when he chose Turner it was someone that

414.50.text:
the public had nominated back last
summer so we're trying to make it far more

418.16.text:
inclusive and give people a chance to
really celebrate the diversity of

422.00.text:
British achievements. Now most of us are
used to five pounds, ten pounds and

425.87.text:
twenties, but we probably have never seen
a 'giant' or a 'titan' - what are those? They're

431.00.text:
one of the really exciting bits of the job,
so, and it's quite a good pub

434.15.text:
quiz question how many Bank of England
denomination notes are there, and most people

438.77.text:
say four, but yes we have 'giants' and
'titans' which are one million and a hundred

443.63.text:
million pound notes. They're not in
general circulation they're actually

447.23.text:
kept very securely in The Bank of
England and they're used really as an

451.04.text:
accounting mechanism largely for
backing assets so the UK is unique in

455.63.text:
that we have a number of commercial
banks in Scotland and Northern Ireland

458.81.text:
who issue their own notes and to ensure
noteholder protection the notes that

463.73.text:
those banks issue are actually fully
backed either by Bank of England notes or UK coin or

469.46.text:
accounts here and rather than having
piles of our new polymer fibers in the

474.35.text:
Volt's we've got these 'giants' and 'titans'.
Figures from the Payments Organisation

478.73.text:
show in the last year that people used
cash less often than other payment

485.87.text:
methods and they reckon that in a few
years time debit cards will overtake the

490.58.text:
use of cash. Do you think that we're
seeing a seismic shift in the way that

495.65.text:
we pay, or that cash has a long and
healthy future? I think that it's great

500.90.text: that there are so many different alternative ways to pay now I mean The Bank of England's

503.78.text:
been issuing banknotes for about 322
years and I think we'll be continuing to

508.70.text: issue them for a long time to come.

511.31.text:
People can now choose credit cards, debit
cards, contactless cards, mobile payments

515.72.text: and things and what we're seeing is that the proportion of transactions in cash is

520.13.text:
gradually slowing so last year it came
below 50% for the first time,

524.72.text:
but it's still very nearly half of all
transactions. But we're still seeing a

529.52.text:
very strong demand for notes overall -
some people using them for transactions, some

534.54.text:
use them more as a store of value, as
contingency, some are abroad in sort of Bureau de Change,

539.70.text:
so the whole range of different things
that drive people to use cash and as

543.93.text:
long as the public demand cash we want
to make sure we can supply notes to them.

547.83.text:
I think that's why it's really important to
invest in the future of notes and hence

550.56.text:
the move to polymer. How about when
you're out shopping, I mean do you prefer to

553.86.text: pay with cash - sort of seeing your signature on the notes - or do you use plastic?

558.42.text:
That's quite exciting when they come out
of the ATM it's oh yes that's one that

562.14.text:
I've signed - there is still a thrill. I'm
not sure if I'll ever get bored of it. But it is

566.70.text:
just a fantastic honour to be signing
my own countries banknotes. I use a

571.53.text:
combination of cash and cards, but
yeah I probably use more cash when I can.

577.26.text:
One of your previous roles at The Bank of
England was in the Special Resolutions,

581.28.text:
which you set up and of course at
the time of Northern Rock, I mean it was

587.31.text:
an extraordinary time, what was it like
to be right at the centre of things when,

593.04.text:
you know, it almost felt like the
financial world was melting. It was

596.34.text:
really exciting, I mean being in a
central bank in a crisis you really want

601.50.text:
to do your best for the public and it's
really setting precedent

605.43.text:
and knowing that things that we were
doing would literally hit the news that

609.12.text:
day, so I think there was a real sense of
collaboration and teamwork. I was working

614.16.text: very closely with a team in the bank but also a number of external consultants from law

618.00.text:
firms, accountants and things and
everyone wanted to come up with the best

622.50.text:
solution. So some very long days, very
late nights but I think it was just the

628.20.text:
adrenaline kept you flowing and having an
opportunity to really influence what was

634.35.text:
going on. So some new legislation was
brought in for Northern Rock, that same

638.88.text:
legislation was used a number of months
later for Bradford and Bingley - I don't know

643.11.text:
at the time we knew that would be used
again, but now we have the Banking Act

647.49.text: 2009, which sets some much clearer guidelines in how to resolve failing institutions. But

653.49.text:
no, it was exciting and at the time
didn't have much of a social life but it

658.71.text:
was absolutely worth it to really be
experiencing what was going on in the

663.56.text: and shaping it. Mark Carney, the Governor of The Bank of England, spoke at the launch of The Women

667.76.text:
in Financial Services Initiative and
said in 2013 I think there were no

671.00.text:
female deputy governors and there were
only 20% of senior

678.38.text:
I'm guessing those kind of statistics,
even though they're changing and the

682.34.text:
bank's set some targets, are not unusual
in financial services. So I think

687.68.text: the statistics as you say were 2013, so in the bank we've already made a big step

692.36.text:
forward so we've now got two women who
are deputy governors and four of the

697.07.text: executive directors are women and I think about 28% of senior

700.73.text:
management so they've already been some
changes which is great. We've set a

704.54.text: target to make 35% by 2020 for senior women in the bank so there's certainly a

711.23.text:
desire to move forward. And we've
always had sort of flexible working but

716.09.text:
I think there's more of a sort of push
to raise the profile of women, to explain

720.83.text:
actually how it can really help a
business to have a more diverse workforce and

725.54.text: also sort of mentoring programs, so I've got three female mentees just to sort of

730.67.text:
try and talk to them about my own
experiences and share ideas with them.

735.62.text:
So I think it's something - it is important
to make sure that women are given an

739.88.text:
opportunity to shine and to contribute.
Some of the numbers are very low - there was

744.95.text:
the Guardian report earlier this year
which is again putting forward some

747.98.text:
really important recommendations to give
women a chance to really use their

752.72.text:
talents. And what would you say to
somebody, a young woman maybe, starting out

757.94.text:
her career in finance who thinks actually
one day I want that job, I want to be

762.41.text: Chief Cashier of The Bank of England? So I think to my mind the most important thing is

766.79.text:
to do things where you think that you
can add value and where you got your

770.66.text:
strengths, not trying to turn yourself
into something completely different and

775.07.text:
also to choose things that you enjoy
doing. I tend to feel I perform better if

779.72.text:
I enjoy something. You have to spend a
lot of time at work, you're really

782.36.text:
putting yourself into it, so enjoy it. See
what other people have achieved - I've

787.85.text:
read that in job applicants women are
typically overqualified, men typically

792.41.text: under-qualified, probably a slight caricature of it, but I think there is a

797.13.text:
Be confident, see what other people have
achieved, don't be afraid of asking for

801.60.text:
I've mentored a number of people and
sometimes it's just saying okay I have

805.56.text: got the confidence, I can do this and yeah do something you enjoy. Victoria Cleland
